awd_titl_txt: Improving Word Production through Comprehension Exposure
awd_abstract_narration:
When children learn their first language, and when adults learn a new language, they are able to understand many words before they begin to use them. In other words, comprehension precedes production. The present research investigates the cognitive processes used for language comprehension and production and whether they are sensitive to a person's prior experience with the language or with particular words. The investigators will also explore whether the way adults learn words presented on their own (as often occurs in language classes) generalizes to everyday language experience (i.e., reading prose, listening to natural speech, and producing natural speech). The research will allow the investigators to determine the cognitive processes that overlap for reading, listening to speech, and producing speech and to assess the durability of memory after these different language experiences. The research activities will increase diversity in research training and participation by including research assistants and research participants from ethnic minority groups in a region with low education and income levels. The research may also have educational implications for vocabulary development of second language learners, both in terms of study techniques for students and teaching practices for educators. 

This project links implicit memory, lexical access, and vocabulary development in controlled experiments with English speakers and Spanish-English bilingual speakers. Word comprehension and production processes are typically investigated separately.  In contrast, the present study explores the impact of comprehension exposures on later production, using a repetition-priming procedure. The first overarching goal is to reveal the nature and durability of memory traces left by auditory and visual comprehension exposures to words as indexed by their impact on later spoken production. Second, the project aims to determine whether patterns of learning elicited by isolated words also result from words seen or heard in sentence contexts. Third, the research addresses fundamental questions about lexical processing that have been debated in the literature, for example, whether comprehension and production processes involve access to common phonological word-form representations, whether comprehension and production involve access to both modality-general and modality-specific representations, and what stages of word production are impacted by experiential variables such as word frequency and language proficiency. More generally, the research is expected to inform models of word production and implicit memory.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
When children learn their first language, and when adults learn a new language, they can understand many words before they begin to use them. In other words, comprehension of new words precedes the ability to use them in speech production. The present research investigated the cognitive processes used for learning in language comprehension and production and whether they are sensitive to a person’s prior experience with the language. When learning vocabulary in a new language by pairing words in the new language with words in a known language, higher proficiency in the known language was associated with more efficient learning. However, bilingual and monolingual speakers of English who were similar in age, education, socio-economic status, and nonverbal cognitive ability did not differ in the efficiency with which they learned.\

Learning does not stop with the initial mapping of words to meanings – with more experience reading, listening to, and speaking particular words, people are able to produce those words more quickly and accurately. In bilingual participants, the experiments showed that a single additional exposure to a known word can elicit long-term learning, as evidenced by faster production a day later. The investigators explored whether the way adults learn from words presented individually (as often occurs in language classes) might generalize to everyday language experience (i.e., reading prose, listening to natural speech, and producing natural speech). Indeed, long-term learning was also evident when words were embedded in sentences. This research also provides information about the relationship between word comprehension and word production by clarifying what sets of cognitive processes and representations overlap for reading words, listening to words, and producing words.

  The results have implications for teaching and learning of vocabulary in native and second languages. Specifically, they suggest that, with respect to fluent production of vocabulary, reading and listening to language in context is helpful. However, translation practice is more effective than simple reading and listening. Also, while practice of vocabulary production is the best practice to speed later production, practice of comprehension helps to increase the probability of successful production. This research also provides insights on the extent to which and circumstances under which reading and listening to speech and translating written or spoken language may help to bring words that are only in receptive vocabulary (words that are comprehended but not produced) into a person's productive vocabulary (words that are both comprehended and produced).

The research activities increased diversity in research training and participation by including research assistants and research participants from under-represented minority groups in a region with low education and income levels. Specifically, four graduate students and nine undergraduate students were trained in research skills while assisting with this project, all but one being members of under-represented minority groups. All thirteen of these students have participated in research presentations, and the majority aspire to careers that involve scientific research. Their participation in this project therefore serves to increase diversity and inclusion in the scientific community. This training and experience make them better prepared for graduate training and for future careers as independent researchers.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Wendy S Francis
